questions.title: Question 1 for Class 191025
questions.main: The initial stage of an air-mass thunderstorm is the:
questions.answer: C) cumulus stage

questions.title: Question 2 for Class 191025
questions.main: The first three stages of a developing hurricane are (from first stage to third stage):
questions.answer: C) tropical disturbance, tropical depression, tropical storm

mcq.option: A) tropical disturbance, tropical storm, typhoon
B) tropical depression, tropical disturbance, tropical storm
C) tropical disturbance, tropical depression, tropical storm

questions.title: Question 3 for Class 191025
questions.main: Describe the stages of development of an ordinary cell (air mass) thunderstorm.
questions.answer: The first stage is known as the cumulus stage or growth stage. As a parcel of warm humid air rises it cools and condenses into a single. cumulus cloud or a cluster of clouds. As the cloud builds the transformation of water vapor into liquid or solid cloud particles releases large quantities of latent heat a process that keeps the rising air inside the cloud warmer (less dense) than the air surrounding it. The cloud continues to grow in the unstable atmosphere as long as it is constantly fed by rising air from below. In this manner a cumulus cloud may show extensive vertical development and grow into a towering cumulus cloud (cumulus congestus) in just a few minutes. During the cumulus stage there normally is insufficient time for precipitation to form and the updrafts keep water droplets and ice crystals suspended within the cloud. Also there is no lightning or thunder during this stage. As the cloud builds well above the freezing level the cloud particles grow larger and heavier as they collide and join with one another. Eventually the rising air is no longer able to keep them suspended and they begin to fall. While this phenomenon is taking place drier air from around the cloud is being drawn into it in a process called entrainment. The entrainment of drier air causes some of the raindrops to evaporate which chills the air. The air now colder and heavier than the air around it begins to descend as a downdraft . The downdraft may be enhanced as falling precipitation drags some of the air along with it. The appearance of the downdraft marks the beginning of the mature stage. During its mature stage the thunderstorm is most intense. The top of the cloud having reached a stable region of the atmosphere (which may be the stratosphere) begins to take on the familiar anvil shape as upper-level winds spread the cloud's ice crystals horizontally.  Lightning and thunder are also present in the mature stage. After the storm enters the mature stage it begins to dissipate in about 15 to 30 minutes. The dissipating stage occurs when the updrafts weaken as the gust front moves away from the storm and no longer enhances the updrafts. At this stage downdrafts tend to dominate throughout much of the cloud. The reason the storm does not normally last very long is that the downdrafts inside the cloud tend to cut off the storm's fuel supply by destroying the humid updrafts. Deprived of the rich supply of warm humid air cloud droplets no longer form.

questions.title: Question 4 for Class 191025
questions.main: The Ekman Spiral describes:
questions.answer: A) the turning of water with depth

mcq.option: A) the turning of water with depth
B) the air flow into a center of low pressure
C) the circulation of surface water around a gyre
D) the air flow out of a region of high pressure
E) the wind-flow pattern in a jet stream

questions.title: Question 5 for Class 191025
questions.main: The turning of water with depth is known as:
questions.answer: B) the Ekman Spiral

questions.title: Question 6 for Class 191025
questions.main: Just before a storm becomes a fully developed hurricane it is in the ____ stage.
questions.answer: C) tropical storm

questions.title: Question 7 for Class 191025
questions.main: If you see a tornado and it appears to be stretched into the shape of a rope what stage of development is the tornado in?
questions.answer: The final stage of a tornado's life cycle called the decay stage usually finds the tornado stretched into the shape of a rope.

questions.title: Question 8 for Class 191025
questions.main: An air-mass thunderstorm is most intense during the ____ stage.
questions.answer: A) mature

questions.title: Question 9 for Class 191025
questions.main: Describe the horizontal and vertical structure of a hurricane.
questions.answer: In a hurricane clouds align themselves into spiraling bands (called spiral rain bands) that swirl in toward the storm's center where they wrap themselves around the eye. Surface winds increase in speed as they blow counterclockwise and inward toward this center. (In the Southern Hemisphere the winds blow clockwise around the center.) Adjacent to the eye is the eyewall a ring of intense thunderstorms that whirl around the storm's center and may extend upward to almost 18 km (59000 ft) above sea level. Within the eyewall we find the heaviest precipitation and the strongest winds.

questions.title: Question 10 for Class 191025
questions.main: How does the average speed of air molecules relate to the air temperature?
questions.answer: Higher temperatures correspond to faster average speeds and lower temperatures to slower average speeds.

questions.title: Question 11 for Class 191025
questions.main: Downdrafts spread throughout a thunderstorm during the ____ stage.
questions.answer: B) dissipating

questions.title: Question 12 for Class 191025
questions.main: Explain this fact: Without upper-level divergence a surface open wave cyclone would probably persist for less than a day.
questions.answer: Air spirals into a surface low due to the effect of friction on air flow. Unless divergence exists above the low it will fill in quickly and dissipate.

questions.title: Question 13 for Class 191025
questions.main: Hurricanes are given names when the storm is in what stage of development?
questions.answer: The name is assigned when the storm reaches tropical storm strength.

questions.title: Question 14 for Class 191025
questions.main: Describe how the wind blows around highs and lows aloft and near the surface in the Northern Hemisphere.
questions.answer: In the Northern Hemisphere air moves in a circular and counter-clockwise manner around low pressure aloft.  At the surface air spirals into the low pressure system in a counter-clockwise manner.

questions.title: Question 15 for Class 191025
questions.main: A group of thunderstorms which develop in a line one next to the other each in a different stage of development are called:
questions.answer: C) a multicell thunderstorm

questions.title: Question 16 for Class 191025
questions.main: What is necessary for a multicell thunderstorm to form?
questions.answer: Multicell storms tend to form in a region of moderate-to-strong vertical wind speed shear. The wind speed increases rapidly with height producing strong wind speed shear. This type of shearing causes the cell inside the storm to tilt in such a way that the updraft actually rides up and over the downdraft.

questions.title: Question 17 for Class 191025
questions.main: Supercell thunderstorms that produce tornadoes form in a region of strong wind shear. Explain how the wind usually changes in speed and direction to produce this shear.
questions.answer: Rapidly increasing wind speed with height provides vertical wind speed shear and the changing wind direction with height - from southerly at low levels to westerly at high levels - provides wind direction shear which induces the updrafts inside the storms to rotate.

questions.title: Question 18 for Class 191025
questions.main: Which of the following provides a measure of the average speed of air molecules:
questions.answer: B) temperature

questions.title: Question 19 for Class 191025
questions.main: An abrupt change in wind speed or wind direction is called:
questions.answer: A) wind shear

questions.title: Question 20 for Class 191025
questions.main: Which instrument only measures wind speed?
questions.answer: A) anemometer

questions.title: Question 21 for Class 191025
questions.main: Severe thunderstorms are different from air-mass thunderstorms in that severe thunderstorms:
questions.answer: E) have a tilted updraft in the mature stage

mcq.option: D) have a strong updraft and downdraft
E) have a tilted updraft in the mature stage

questions.title: Question 22 for Class 191025
questions.main: The main difference between a hurricane and a tropical storm is that:
questions.answer: C) winds speeds are greater in a hurricane

mcq.option: B) tropical storms are more than 500 miles from the US mainland
C) winds speeds are greater in a hurricane
D) hurricanes have a clearly defined eye on satellite photographs

questions.title: Question 23 for Class 191025
questions.main: Which of the following forces can not act to change the speed of the wind?
questions.answer: C) Coriolis force

questions.title: Question 24 for Class 191025
questions.main: On a piece of paper draw the different stages of a mid- latitude cyclonic storm as it goes through birth to decay according to the polar front (Norwegian) model.
questions.answer: (NO ANSWER PROVIDED)

questions.title: Question 25 for Class 191025
questions.main: Explain why condensation is more likely when the air temperature lowers.
questions.answer: Condensation is more likely to happen as the air cools because the speed of the vapor molecules decreases. As the air temperature increases condensation is less likely because most of the molecules have sufficient speed (sufficient energy) to remain as a vapor.

questions.title: Question 26 for Class 191025
questions.main: An instrument used to measure wind speed is called a(an):
questions.answer: A) anemometer

questions.title: Question 27 for Class 191025
questions.main: Lines of equal wind speed are called:
questions.answer: C) isotachs

questions.title: Question 28 for Class 191025
questions.main: Charged particles from the sun that travel through space at high speeds are called:
questions.answer: C) solar wind

questions.title: Question 29 for Class 191025
questions.main: Which of the instruments below indicates both wind speed and wind direction?
questions.answer: B) aerovane

questions.title: Question 30 for Class 191025
questions.main: The greatest wind speed ever recorded at the earth's surface occurred at:
questions.answer: A) Mt. Washington, New Hampshire

questions.title: Question 31 for Class 191025
questions.main: Explain how suction vortices can add wind speed to a large multi-vortex tornado.
questions.answer: The surging nature of the main cold front itself or developing cumulus clouds along the front.

questions.title: Question 32 for Class 191025
questions.main: Describe the weather conditions necessary for a blizzard to form over the northern Great Plains.
questions.answer: A blizzard implies strong winds hence the storm requires a strong pressure gradient.  A strong pressure gradient will occur when the central pressure of the storm is exceptionally low which can occur is exceptionally strong divergence occurs over the cyclone.  To get a strong divergence requires a strong jet stream which in turn requires an intense temperature gradient at the surface.

questions.title: Question 33 for Class 191025
questions.main: The region in the United States with the greatest annual frequency of hailstones is:
questions.answer: D) the western Great Plains

questions.title: Question 34 for Class 191025
questions.main: List three 'triggers' that help in the initial stage of hurricane development.
questions.answer: 1. Convergence of air along the ITCZ  2. An easterly wave  3. Pre-exiting atmospheric disturbance (remnant front)

questions.title: Question 35 for Class 191025
questions.main: Why do some mid-latitude cyclones quickly 'die out' after they become occluded?
questions.answer: The divergence aloft which removes air over the cyclone follows the place where temeprature contrast at the surface is greatest. Afterr the storm occludes the location of greatest temperature contrast shifts away from the center of the cyclone.

questions.title: Question 36 for Class 191025
questions.main: What are the necessary ingredients for a mid-latitude cyclonic storm to develop into a huge storm system?
questions.answer: Upper-level divergence (usually associated with a shortwave) surface convergence strong horizontal temperature contrast temperature advection.

questions.title: Question 37 for Class 191025
questions.main: If the flow of air into a surface low pressure area is greater than the divergence of air aloft the surface pressure in the center of the low will:
questions.answer: A) increase

questions.title: Question 38 for Class 191025
questions.main: The wind's speed generally increases with height above the earth's surface because:
questions.answer: D) friction with the earth's surface slows the air near the ground

mcq.option: A) only the lowest layer of air rotates with the earth
B) air temperature normally decreases with height
C) wind instruments are not accurate at the earth's surface
D) friction with the earth's surface slows the air near the ground
E) air parcels expand and become less dense as they rise above the surface

questions.title: Question 39 for Class 191025
questions.main: If the earth did not rotate how would surface winds tend to blow?
questions.answer: If the earth did not rotate there would be no Coriolis force.  Air would expand on the warm side of the earth (towards the sun) causing a high pressure aloft.  Air would flow aloft toward the cold side and hence add mass to the cold area causing surface pressure there to rise.  The higher pressure at the surface would cause flow back to the warm side.

questions.title: Question 40 for Class 191025
questions.main: In calm air the air temperature is -10 degrees C if the wind speed should increase to 30 knots (with no change in air temperature) the thermometer would indicate:
questions.answer: C) a temperature of -10¬∞C

mcq.option: A) a much higher temperature than -10¬∞C
B) a much lower temperature than -10¬∞C

questions.title: Question 41 for Class 191025
questions.main: Atmospheric shortwaves usually move ____ at a speed that is ____ than longwaves.
questions.answer: B) west to east, faster

questions.title: Question 42 for Class 191025
questions.main: The instrument that measures the speed at which precipitation is moving toward or away from an observer is:
questions.answer: D) Doppler radar

questions.title: Question 43 for Class 191025
questions.main: In what ways is a hurricane different from a mid-latitude cyclone? In what ways are these two systems similar?
questions.answer: Similarities: both have central cores of low pressure and winds that spiral counterclockwise about their respective centers (Northern Hemisphere). Differences: a hurricane derives its energy from the warm water and the latent heat of condensation whereas the mid-latitude storm derives its energy from horizontal temperature contrasts. The vertical structure of a hurricane is such that its central column of air is warm from the surface upward; consequently hurricanes are called warmcore lows. A hurricane weakens with height and the area of low pressure at the surface may actually become an area of high pressure above 12 kilometers (40000 feet). Mid-latitude cyclones on the other hand are cold-core lows that usually intensify with increasing height with a cold upper-level low or trough often existing above or to the west of the surface low. A hurricane usually contains an eye where the air is sinking while mid-latitude cyclones are characterized by centers of rising air. Hurricane winds are strongest near the surface whereas the strongest winds of the mid-latitude storm are found aloft in the jet stream.

questions.title: Question 44 for Class 191025
questions.main: If katabatic winds blow downslope why aren't they warm?
questions.answer: The ideal setting for a katabatic wind is an elevated plateau surrounded by mountains with an opening that slopes rapidly downhill. When winter snows accumulate on the plateau the overlying air grows extremely cold and a shallow dome of high pressure forms near the surface. Along the edge of the plateau the horizontal pressure gradient force is usually strong enough to cause the cold air to flow across the isobars through gaps and saddles in the hills. Along the slopes of the plateau the wind continues downhill as a gentle or moderate cold breeze. If the horizontal pressure gradient increases substantially such as when a storm approaches or if the wind is confined to a narrow canyon or channel the flow of air can increase often destructively as cold air rushes down-slope like water flowing over a waterfall. Even though the sinking air warms by compression it is so cold to begin with that it isn't much warmer than the air it replaces.

questions.title: Question 45 for Class 191025
questions.main: In winter cold-front weather is typically more violent than warm-front weather. Why? Explain why this situation is not necessarily true in summer.
questions.answer: The temperature contrast across a wintertime cold front can be much larger than the contrast across a summertime cold front.  The most violent weather occurs when the temperature contrast is larger.

questions.title: Question 46 for Class 191025
questions.main: A wind that blows at a constant speed parallel to curved isobars or contour lines is called a:
questions.answer: D) gradient wind

questions.title: Question 47 for Class 191025
questions.main: On average where do we usually find the highest dew-point temperatures in the United States?
questions.answer: In the southeast.

questions.title: Question 48 for Class 191025
questions.main: Which forecasting method assumes that weather systems will move in the same direction and at the same speed as they have been moving?
questions.answer: E) steady state (trend) forecast

questions.title: Question 49 for Class 191025
questions.main: A sonic boom:
questions.answer: E) is caused when an aircraft flies faster than the speed of sound

mcq.option: A) is a form of lightning
C) is produced by static electricity in the atmosphere
D) can be produced by an approaching tornado
E) is caused when an aircraft flies faster than the speed of sound

questions.title: Question 50 for Class 191025
questions.main: The net force on air moving in a circle at constant speed is:
questions.answer: A) inward toward the center of rotation

mcq.option: A) inward toward the center of rotation
C) in the direction of wind motion
D) outward from the center of rotation
